title: Break out examples in tutorial dir into their own projects
body:
It's great that we have been adding new examples of using MLflow inside of `example/tutorial` but it is also confusing to new users because `tutorial` is an MLflow project (i.e it has an `MLProject` file inside of it it) that demonstrates using MLflow to run and track training a Scikit-learn linear model using  the wine csv dataset as the input.

Also it's confusing that we currently have a `quickstart` and a `tutorial` dir without any explanation of what the difference is. We should consider deleting the quickstart dir or at least adding a README to explain why it exists and how it's different than the tutorials.

It would be much more instructive to new users if we organized the tutorials so that each is a separate MLflow project. Can have the structure be something like:

```
examples
    |-  tutorial-1-sklearn-linear-regression
    |-  tutorial-2-tensorflow-dnn
    |-  tutorial-3-pytorch-dnn-tensorboard
    |-  tutorial-4-sklearn-diabetes-jupyter
    |-  tutorial-5-h20-random-forests
    |-  tutorial-6-advanced-mlflow-api-usage
```

An alternative is for us to officially make https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow-apps the golden repository of all example "apps" and just point to that from a README inside of the `example` dir. Though, as a side note, that repo should probably be called mlflow-example-projects instead of mlflow-apps (since MLflow doesn't refer to them as apps, they are projects!).

Why should we have the mlflow-apps repository be separate from what's in the `example` dir? How should we decide what should go where between the two?
